title: Mammography in combination with breast ultrasonography versus mammography for breast cancer screening in women at average risk
authors: Glechner, A; Wagner, G; Mitus, JW; Teufer, B; Klerings, I; Böck, N; Grillich, L; Berzaczy, D; Helbich, TH; Gartlehner, G

response.output:
Plain Language Summary Title
Adding an ultrasound to a mammogram for breast cancer screening: does it help?

Key Messages
– For women at average risk of breast cancer, having an ultrasound scan as well as a mammogram can find more breast cancers than having a mammogram alone. The cancers found with this combined method are also less likely to have spread.

– However, adding an ultrasound to a mammogram also leads to more "false alarms." This is when a test suggests cancer might be present, but it is not. These false alarms lead to more women needing extra tests, like a biopsy (where a small piece of tissue is removed to be checked for cancer cells), even though they do not have cancer.

– We do not know if finding more cancers by adding an ultrasound helps women live longer, because the studies did not look at this.

What is breast cancer screening?
Breast cancer screening aims to find cancer early, before any symptoms appear. Finding cancer early can make it easier to treat.

The most common screening test is a mammogram, which is a special X-ray of the breast. Sometimes, an ultrasound scan is also used. An ultrasound uses sound waves to create a picture of the inside of the breast.

Some women have "dense" breast tissue, which has less fat and more connective and glandular tissue. Dense breasts can make it harder to see cancer on a mammogram.

What did we want to find out?
We wanted to find out if adding an ultrasound to a mammogram was better than a mammogram alone for breast cancer screening. We looked at this for women who have an average risk of getting breast cancer.

We were interested in:
– how many breast cancers were found
– how many women died from breast cancer or any other cause
– how many cancers were found in the time between regular screenings
– unwanted effects, like being told you might have cancer when you do not (a "false-positive" result) or needing a biopsy when you do not have cancer.

What did we do?
We searched for studies that compared using a mammogram plus an ultrasound with using a mammogram alone for breast cancer screening. The studies had to include women between 40 and 75 years old who were at average risk of breast cancer.

We compared and summarized the results of the studies. We also rated our confidence in the evidence, based on factors such as how the studies were done and how large they were.

What did we find?
We found 8 studies that included about 209,000 women. The studies followed the women for 1 to 3 years.

Our main findings came from one large, well-done study. The other studies supported these findings.

Finding more cancers
Adding an ultrasound to a mammogram found more breast cancers than a mammogram alone. The cancers found with the combined screening were also less likely to have spread to the lymph nodes (glands near the breast). Also, fewer cancers were found in the time between scheduled screenings when women had both tests.

Downsides of adding an ultrasound
The combined screening method led to more false alarms. This means more women were told they might have cancer when they did not. Because of this, more women who did not have cancer ended up having a biopsy.

What we still don't know
None of the studies we found looked at whether adding an ultrasound to screening helped women live longer.

Results for women with dense breasts
For women with dense breasts, adding an ultrasound also helped find more cancers. The evidence was less clear for women who did not have dense breasts.

What are the limitations of the evidence?
We are confident that adding an ultrasound to a mammogram finds more cancers but also causes more false alarms and unnecessary biopsies.

However, the biggest limitation is that we do not know the long-term effects. The studies were not long enough to tell us if finding these extra cancers actually saves lives. We need longer studies to understand if this screening approach reduces deaths from breast cancer.

How up to date is this evidence?
The evidence is up to date to May 2021.
